pr_title: Make TestSourceTest more tolerant to hiccups

timeline.bodyText: I'd prefer not to depend on Guava for tests, you can rewrite this easily using IntStream.range(). Also it's not clear why you're asserting itemsPerSecond - 1 or itemsPerSecond + 1, maybe the test should be rewritten completely in a more deterministic way.
timeline.author: cangencer

timeline.message: Make test more tolerant to hick-ups

timeline.bodyText: this will throw IllegalArgumentException because you can get a negative number here
timeline.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText: I don't see how I could get a negative number there, until windowsToConsider = Math.min(5, windowResults.size()).
replies.author: jbartok

replies.bodyText: yes, you are right, my bad
replies.author: cangencer

timeline.bodyText: now if there is just 1 window and it has 9 items, the test will pass. That's not a very strong assertion.
timeline.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText: If there is 1 window with 9 items, then deviationFromTarget = 1, which is not smaller than the allowed tolerance of 0.1, so it won't pass, but wait for more windows.
replies.author: jbartok

replies.bodyText: ok, again I read it thinking it was a percentage, but it's actually an absolute value.
replies.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText: how long does the test take to pass?
replies.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText:
On my machine it always takes 5 seconds to pass, but unfortunately it's not the test that's bad, but the first window always has way less values than it should, usually at most 7, instead of 10.
And that usually only in the "member" mode, the subsequent "client" mode is better, usually starts with a 9.
Feels like a warmup, but I'm not sure what it is. Looking at it.
replies.author: jbartok

replies.bodyText: how about we always skip the first window?
replies.author: cangencer

replies.bodyText: Good idea, pushed that version, much better.
replies.author: jbartok
